title: Orbital energy - change in comets kinetic energy

content.description: A comet of mass <math alttext="m sub c equals, 3.2 times 10 to the 14 power kilograms" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>m</mi><mi>c</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>3.2</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>14</mn></msup><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>kg</mi></mstyle></math> is orbiting a star with mass <math alttext="m sub s equals, 1.8 times 10 to the 30 power kilograms" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>m</mi><mi>s</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>1.8</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>30</mn></msup><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>kg</mi></math>. The comet’s orbit is elliptical. At its closest point, the comet is a distance <math alttext="r sub 1 equals, 8.3 times 10 to the 10 power meters" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>r</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>8.3</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>10</mn></msup><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mstyle></math> from the star, and at its farthest point, the comet is a distance <math alttext="r sub 2 equals, 4.9 times 10 to the 11 power meters" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>4.9</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>11</mn></msup><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mstyle></math>.
content.question: What is the change in the kinetic energy of the comet as it moves along its orbit from distance <math alttext="r sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> to distance <math alttext="r sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>r</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> from the star?
